stream_context.summary: Kaze spends almost the entire stream white-boarding Course 15, “Space / Asteroid Arcade,” for Return to Yoshi’s Island, turning vague ideas into a concrete level blueprint.

development_findings.summary: Course 15 will be a space-themed arcade built around a central rocket ship hub with three major paths and an interior arcade room; a pinball-style flipper field holding the red coins sits beneath the main platforms and shoots the player back up.
development_findings.quote: The flipper star and all the flipper platforms are below the main course and shoot you up if you move around it.

development_findings.summary: Primary design goals: 1) ‘Fun, freedom’ movement, 2) Absolute certainty of objectives, 3) Awe through lights/visuals, 4) Maintain an open feel even though the path is functionally linear.
development_findings.quote: Most important order of business, do not ever have the player question what to do… freedom in how to achieve those goals movement-wise.

development_findings.summary: Low-gravity zones, black-hole/teleporter warps, and limited wing-cap / cloud-cap pickups will supply movement variety without breaking linear guidance.

Arcade mini-game stars chosen: a Tetris chamber where falling pieces threaten Mario, and a 3-D Pac-Man maze (Chain Chomps as ghosts). Whack-a-Mole and rhythm-game concepts were rejected as too close to existing content or unclear.
development_findings.quote: I think Pac-Mario… we make it so that the player jumps into it and the Chain Chomps that are in the labyrinth are really fast.

development_findings.summary: New enemy set planned: ‘space Shy Guys’ (lanky, possibly spinning attack) and ‘space Skeeters’; overall enemy count kept low because mechanical hazards dominate the level.
Kaze debated Galaxy-style “six layout” acts that reconfigure geometry per star but worries about Yoshi-coin consistency; idea remains open.
development_findings.quote: I’m thinking maybe the secret sauce here is to make the level change per act… then I’m thinking… it makes the Yoshi coins weird.

development_findings.summary: Engine test shows the empty Space Arcade runs stable 60 FPS on real N64 hardware, even with all enhancements enabled.
development_findings.quote: I’d say this level runs pretty well on N64 so far… still stable 60. That’s just how powerful the engine is.

development_findings.summary: Course 1 demo is finished; public demo release targeted for early January 2025 (after Christmas) on the ‘KazeClips’ channel to minimize Nintendo takedown risk.
development_findings.quote: I’m thinking I will release it shortly after Christmas… probably like first of next year or something.

development_findings.summary: Entire RTYI engine will be open-sourced once the full game ships; Kaze will not release it earlier because it would leak the game.
development_findings.quote: I am planning to open source it. The problem is if I open source it right now I’m going to open source it with my entire game.

context_findings.summary: Kaze’s design philosophy prioritizes ‘edging’—showing sights that build anticipation—while guaranteeing the player always knows the next objective.
context_findings.quote: You can’t put something out there and have the player anticipate what it is… edging the player is important.

context_findings.summary: He dislikes overly linear experiences (criticizes Mario Galaxy’s reuse of paths) and holds his own project to a higher content standard.
context_findings.quote: Maybe I am holding my game to way too high of a standard.

context_findings.summary: Concerned about Nintendo legal action; avoids releasing builds around Christmas and will use his secondary channel for the demo.
Shows mild frustration with repetitive Roblox requests and chat distractions, pacing around while ‘thinking.’
context_findings.quote: What are you doing? I’m thinking!

context_findings.summary: Mentions early career pride: split-screen Mario 64 on N64 was written in his first week of C after MIPS assembly.

biobak.summary: Earlier assets for Space Arcade (asteroids, rocket, arcade props) were created by Biobak; Kaze re-uses them from the Scuttlebug hack submission.
Kaze notes he might adopt Biobak’s idea for placing the 8-bit pipe but hasn’t decided.

key_stories.title: Cracking the Space Arcade layout
key_stories.summary: Kaze wrestles with the central dilemma of making a course that feels open yet always shows the player where to go. After studying Mario Galaxy and several chat suggestions, he settles on a central rocket hub, three branching paths, low-gravity teleporters, and a flipper field underneath.
key_stories.challenge: Blend non-linear ‘fun freedom’ with clear objectives in a sprawling space level.
key_stories.process: Brainstormed goals, listed failed ideas, analyzed Galaxy’s structure, sketched diagrams live on stream, tested engine limits.
key_stories.outcome: A concrete macro layout is finalized; micro-design to begin next session.
key_stories.key_quote: This is slowly shaping into something… I think I’ve got a good idea for what the level should be like now.

key_stories.title: Demo timing vs. Nintendo
key_stories.summary: The Course 1 demo is ready, but Kaze fears holiday-season DMCA strikes. He decides to delay until early 2025 and host it on his smaller channel.
key_stories.challenge: Release a public build without drawing immediate legal fire.
key_stories.process: Weighed calendar timing, discussed prior takedowns, chose alternate channel.
key_stories.outcome: Demo penciled in for January 2025 on ‘KazeClips.’
key_stories.key_quote: If you release stuff around Christmas, Nintendo gets very angry.

key_stories.title: Open-sourcing the engine
key_stories.summary: Fans request an early code drop for testing, but Kaze worries it would leak the entire game.
key_stories.challenge: Balance community collaboration with protecting unfinished content.
key_stories.outcome: Engine will go public only after full game launch.
key_stories.key_quote: It will be open source once it’s finished, so don’t worry about that.

open_questions.context: Kaze wants unpredictable warps that don’t show their destination to preserve exploration but hasn’t detailed how they’ll be taught to the player.
questions: How will you convey teleporter rules so players aren’t confused?
Will there be visual or audio cues to distinguish black holes vs. teleport pads?
Are there performance limits on multiple distant sub-areas?”],
